results.title: Arts of Japan
results.brief_description: This film tells the story of a young American who visits artists of Japan, including the painter Gyokudo Kawai, tea master Soshitsu Sen, actors Koshiro Mataumoto and Manzaburo Umewaka, potter Shoju Hamada, and wood-block artist Shiko Manakata. Includes scenes from the Noh and Kabuki dramas.

results.title: Arts in society
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
A program in which archival footage has been selected to provide students with some background on the influence of the arts in Australians’ lives.

results.title: Artists of Mt Best
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Dean Lawry and ACMI
results.brief_description: Mt Best is full of artists who have been inspired by the beauty, changing light and drama of this region in the Strezlecki Ranges. In this film we meet painters, photographers and musicians who talk about what drew them to the area, how the weather informs their work and how the community inspire each other.

results.title: Artists of Eldorado
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet local artists Maureen Hearn, Denise Ellison, Thea Day, Sandra Buchan and Sam Anderson, and learn about their inspirations and artistic practice. Moved by the magic of Eldorado, in northern Victoria, these artists are never short of inspiration. Day, Ellison and Buchan make time each week to get together and share their passion for painting and line drawing. Hearn works out of her studio that showcases her love of the river and obsession with chickens. Anderson is a metal sculptor who works on his family farm creating large scale works, such as his ‘Gorilla’, which must be seen to be believed.

results.title: Artists must live
results.creator_credit: John Read, John Elliot, Great Britain Arts Council and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Explores the relationship between the artist and his patron. Shows the problems facing contemporary artists and the opportunities offered by institutional and industrial sponsors, the modern successors to wealthy private patrons. Painters and sculptors featured in this film include John Piper, Keith Vaughan, Patrick Heron, Ridrigo Moynihan, Evor Hitchens, Reg Butler, Clifford Ellis, J.M.W. Turner, Jacob Epstein and Henry Moore. The narrator is the well-known art critic Basil Taylor; the film includes scenes at the Slade School, the Bath Academy, the Tate Gallery, and other centres of art in Britain.

results.title: Artists in cyberculture
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Cohen, Frances McGivern and Cracked Metal Productions
results.brief_description: Artists record their work at the Third International Symposium on Electronic Art, Sydney, 1992. Through a series of interviews, performance, electronic theatre, this video looks at ways in which artists challenge the emerging technological realm known as “cyberculture”. It also examines issues such as gender, the body, the homogenisation of culture and the social and environmental implications of new technologies. Three of the artists interviewed are Char Davies, Stelarc and Myron Kreuger.

results.title: Artists and models
results.creator_credit: Frank Tashlin, Hal B Wallis and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: In this satirical slapstick comedy Dean Martin plays Rick Todd, a fledging painter who has relocated to New York in search of acclaim. Eugene, Rick’s best friend and housemate also has ambitions, as a children’s writer, but his clumsy antics continuously lose them menial jobs that they land. Despite their misfortunes the impoverished pair dream of greater things, such as food, girls, money and fame. Along the way, the friends woo their luscious neighbours, comic book artist Abigail (Dorothy Malone) and her model, Bessie (Shirley MacLaine). When Abigail resigns after being asked to beef up her storylines with more blood and gore, Rick takes her job, using Eugene’s ecstatic and vivid dreams as material. Eugene dreams up the secret formula for rocket fuel, and enemy agents are soon on his tail. Several musical interludes pepper the film that is alight with sight gags, physical and madcap humour, and despite its largely formulaic approach, is one of the finest Lewis and Martin comedies made as a duo.

results.title: Artists and artisans at Orrefors
results.brief_description: Artists and artisans at work in the Orrefors glass-works in Sweden. We see how they design their work, how they find aesthetic and practical solutions to functional problems, and all stages of the blowing of glass. Artists hand-paint designs onto glass, then they hand-engrave the design to complete the article. Many fine examples of Orrefors glassware are included. No credits available.
